text: The end of Winter.  SNOW blankets the landscape.  A SMALL STREAM rushes through the VALLEY.  A clear, blue sky hang the DISTANT MOUNTAINS adding to the beauty of the setting
The CAMERA begins to PAN.  The color of the SNOW begins t change, darkening from PURE WHITE to ASH GRAY, eventually COAL BLACK.  We continue to pan until we arrive at..

Plague.  Once a charming settlement it is now ravaged by disease.  Everywhere BONFIRES burn, sending plumes of BLA SMOKE rising into the sky -- the ash and soot drift back blackening the earth.  VILLAGERS scurry about in tattered clothing, their faces soiled by soot as they throw object WOOD and CLOTH into the fires. THREE HORSEMEN ride into the village.  Two of them we can clearly as large, powerful men with savage faces.  The TH MAN'S man's face is hidden from us in the shadows of a bl HOODED CAPE. No windows.  The Hooded Man enters.  In the center of the a CIRCLE has been drawn.  Bordering the circle are hundre CANDLES, forming a ring of fire.  A MAN stands in the cen his head bowed -- his weight supported by thick ROPES aro his wrists that are fastened to a wooden beam which runs length of the room.

Vieira... VIEIRA looks up.  He is old, his hair thin and gray, but eyes are alive, defiant.  The Hooded Man moves closer.  V follows him with his eyes, trying to see the Hooded Man's Vieira strains against his ropes.  The Hooded Man does no move.
How comes it your are not afraid?
Would'st you harm one who comes to aid you? Vieira's silence indicates he is listening.
(continuing) I've come to strike a bargain with you.  I wish to learn the power of changing.
And what would'st I gain from this bargain?
(nonchalantly) Your life.
How? The Hooded Man slowly pulls back his hood.  We see his fa the first time.  It is hard, brutal, his eyes cold and da He grins -- a wicked grin.

I have a magic of my own. The Hooded Man removes a KNIFE from under his coat.  He h it before Vieira, then he quickly stabs it into his chest face fills with pain -- blood flows from the wound -- he to his knees.  A beat.  He slowly looks up at Vieira as h pulls the knife from his chest, then stands unharmed.  Vi cannot believe what he has seen.
Teach me the chant and I will take your place on the gallows.
A GROUP of RELIGIOUS-LOOKING MEN walk toward the church.
Vieira has finished teaching the chant.

After you recite the chant you must concentrate of the form you wish to take.  The stonger you are the longer you can hold the illusion. In the b.g. we HEAR the SOUND of FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs.  Vieira looks at the Hooded Man.
They come.  Quickly, take my place. The Men enter.  One of them looks at the Hooded Man.
What are you doing here? The Hooded Man stares at him -- a hard, unnerving stare - slowly, his thin lips from a cruel grin.
Just saying goodbye to an old friend. Vieira stares at the Hooded Man angrily.
We had a bargain.  You promised.
I lied. The Hooded Man walks from the room.
The Hooded Man walks out.  The TWO HORSEMEN ride up.  The Hooded Man climbs on his horse.  He takes a DEEP BREATH a looks at a RANGE OF MOUNTAINS in the distance.

The SOUND of SWORDS CROSSING fill the air.  Two MEN, one the other OLD fight across the SNOW-SWEPT GROUND.  In. th a large, stone building is built at the base of a mountai range. The Young Man fights furiously, his only weapon strength, he is clearly inexperienced.  The OLD MAN is agile, and e moves out of the way of each blow.  The Young Man swings wildly, he loses his balance.  The Old Man strikes his SW away, then pushes him to the ground.  The Young Man looks the older man raises his SWORD above his head.  Their eye lock.  The Old Man smiles and slowly lowers the sword to Young Man's neck.
It's over. The Old Man reaches out his hand, helping the Young Man t feet.  The Young Man is clearly angry.
Your anger blinds you.  You must learn to control it.  When the time comes you'll only have but one chance.  You best use it well.

Large and barren.  A fires roars in the fireplace.  The O sits across a wooden table from the Young man as they fin eating. The Young Man appears restless.  He pushes his plate away -- stands up and walks toward the door.
Where are you off to?

To the village for some ale -- and if the truth be known, I need to see someones face other than yours, old man. They smile.  The Young Man takes his SWORD then puts on h COAT.  He picks up a SACK and leaves.  The Old Man begins clear away the dishes.  Suddenly he stops -- his smile fa He looks towards the door filled with a premonition.  Out we HEAR the SOUND of SWORDS CROSSING.  It lasts only for moment.  SILENCE. A blinding GREEN LIGHT fills the frame of the door.  The begins to TREMBLE -- the STONES of the building shake fro force -- debris falls from the ceiling.  It stops.  SILEN The Old Man takes his SWORD from the mantle.  The DOOR OP The SOUND of the WIND rushes in.  Outside nothing can be - only the darkness of the night.  A beat.  The Young Man enters the room.  The Old Man smiles at the sight of him. Young Man places his sack on the table. The Old Man turns his back as he starts to replace his sw the mantle.  The Young Man's expression hardens.  He star the Old Man's neck as he starts to raise his sword.

In a SILVER WINE CHALICE he sees the reflection of the YO MAN who is now slowly raising his SWORD and about to stri the Old Man's neck. In one fluid movement the Old Man unsheathes his sword, t turns quickly.  The Young Man's blade slices through the missing it's target.  The Old Man pivots and slices his b across the Young Man's chest.  The Young Man winces in pa then takes a deep breath -- his body begins to shake viol A TRANSFORMATION BEGINS.  The image of Young Man begins t and is replaced by the HOODED MAN.  He LAUGHS LOUDLY as h holds up his arms as if prompting The Old Man for his appreciation of the illusion.
(hatefully) Kilvara... The Hooded Man smiles when he hears his name.
It flatters me you remember, old one. It's been what... two hundred years?
It's not been long enough.  What witchcraft is this?
Impressive -- is it not?  The problem is I can only keep the illusion for a few minutes.  I need more power to hold the form longer.  I need the Highlander.  Where is he?
I do not know -- and even if I did...

(cutting him off) I know.  I know-- you would not tell me.  Loyalty -- it really is a concept that eludes me. (shrugs his shoulders) Oh well -- I shall find him.  Time is on my side. The Old Man looks sadly at the open door.  Kilvara notice grins.

Is this what you're looking for? Kilvara opens the SACK.  Inside it is the head of the You Man.  Kilvara LAUGHS, a deep guttural laugh.  He turns an starts towards the door.  Suddenly he stops and turns bac face the Old Man.
(mockingly) Oh -- I almost forgot.  Your head.
It does not come off as easily as the young ones.

(amused) Perhaps -- but it comes off none the less. With a savage YELL Kilvara draws his sword and lunges at Old Man.  The Old Man steps aside and Kilvara's sword sma down on the table, shattering it into splinters. The two Horsemen step into the room and watch.  Kilvara l again -- and again -- each time the Old Man side-steps hi Kilvara swings -- the Old Man ducks -- the blade hits the wall -- SPARKS FLY -- ROCK EXPLODES.  The Old Man slices blade across Kilvara chest.  A deep gash is cut -- blood Kilvara examines the wound.

You're dead. With brutal strength Kilvara begins his attack again, whi his sword through the air furiously.  Their swords cross sparks fly.  Kilvara is too powerful for the Old Man.  Al can do is back up -- using his sword to block each feroci blow.  They pass through a large ARCH at the rear of the

The building is built at the mouth of a vast CAVE.  TORCH in the walls of the cavern are the only source of light. WOODEN BRIDGE is built over a deep RAVINE.  Kilvara and t Man continue their fight across the bridge.  The Horsemen behind, enjoying the battle.  The Old Man's strength is g way under the merciless attack. The SPARKS from each contact is even more dazzling in the light of the cavern.  Kilvara swings again.  The Old Man to block it.  In one fluid movement Kilvara scrapes his S along the Old Man's -- then lunges forward -- thrusting h blade through the Old Man's chest.  The Old Man SCREAMS i pain.  Kilvara lifts him up with the blade.  Kilvara flin off the blade and onto the ground.  The Old Man is on his knees.  Kilvara raises his sword above his head.

There can be only one. Kilvara brings the blade down.  It slices through the Old neck, severing his head from his body.  Kilvara waits, preparing himself.  A stream of bright GREEN LIGHT begins flow from the BODY of the OLD MAN.  It grows BRIGHTER and BRIGHTER.  The Body of the old man begins to hover above ground, then in a pulsing burst of energy the LIGHT flows Kilvara.  The force knocks him to his knees. The GROUND SHAKES -- The walls of the cavern move.  Sudde chunks of rock are blown out of the walls -- the RUMBLING grows LOUDER and LOUDER -- blinding GREEN LIGHT FILLS the and then -- a deafening EXPLOSION.  Whole sections of the cavern begin to collapse -- covering the exit -- trapping everyone inside.
The RUMBLING SOUND subsides.  In the distance we hear the savage SCREAM of Kilvara.  The CAMERA MOVES UP the side o mountain.  As we come over the top we see...
The familiar towers of the city skyline stand along the b their LIGHTS reflecting off the water.
A thick FOG hangs in the air.  A light wind blows, moving newspapers and other articles of trash along the deserted street.
Crates and trash dumpsters line the alley.  A single, nak light bulb shines down like a spotlight.  Through the fog SILHOUETTE of man appears as he steps under the light.

We follow the man from behind.  He is tall, dressed in a tan rain-coat, jeans and sneakers.  A small TRAVEL BAG is over his shoulder.  As he moves down the alley he hears a SCRAPING SOUND.  HE stops -- but does not turn around. A street PUNK emerges from behind a trash crate, scraping BLADE of his KNIFE along the wall of a building.  He stud the man for a moment as he runs his thumb along the edge blade, almost caressing it.
What'cha got in the bag? Not only does the man not answer -- he doesn't even turn around.

Hey -- you hear me? CONNER MACLEOD slowly turns around.  He is mid thirties, handsome, his chin dotted with the stubble of a beard.  H calm, detached -- yet under the surface there is a great sadness from a lifetime of pain and loneliness.  He stare the Punk wearily -- knowing both what is going to happen what the outcome will be.
(softly) Yes -- I hear you.
Good.  Now, give it up. Macleod studies the Punk for a moment.

Go home -- while you still can. Macleod turns his back to him and starts to walk away.  T Punk moves after him quickly.  Macleod reaches into a tra and pulls out a piece of PIPE.  The Punk stops and stares Macleod.
(amused) What do you think you're gonna to do with that? Macleod raises the pipe, twirling it around expertly in h hand.
(deadly calm) Let's find out. A beat.  The Punk is losing confidence.  He looks at Macl

Deep.  Confidant.  They radiate an intensity that seems t into the Punk. The Punk is unnerved by Macleod's calm.  Macleod waits, l him make the next move.  A beat.  The Punk backs away and disappears into the darkness.  Macleod stares him for a m then drops the pipe to the ground and walks off in the ot direction.
Macleod stops at the mouth of the alley where it intersec with the street.  He stares across the street.

An old building.  A sign reads:  RUSSELL NASH, ANTIQUES. A sadness falls across his face -- his mind floods with memories as he looks at the building. Across the street the door of the antique store opens.  R an attractive woman in her fifties exits -- locks the doo walks down the street. Macleod watches her affectionately -- painfully.  As she crosses the street, he steps back into the shadows of the alley, hiding in the darkness.  Rachel reaches the alley, stops -- thinks -- looks back at the Antique Store.  She only a few feet away from Macleod.
Macleod struggles to make a decision.  Slowly he raises h hand -- reaches out -- but cannot bring himself to touch Rachel starts to walk away.

Rachel. No more needs to be said.  She recognizes the voice insta She turns around slowly and looks behind her.  In the b.g Macleod steps out of the darkness.  He smiles at her weak Confusion fills her face, but is quickly replaced by a wa emotion.  She moves towards Macleod slowly, as if trying determine if he is really there.  She cups her hands to h face and stares deeply into his eyes.  No words are spoke none need to be.  The power of their feelings are shown i their eyes.
Crowded with tables, chairs, cabinets and other rare old objects of furniture.  Macleod is seated at a 17th centur dinning table.  Rachel stands in the center of the room.
You know it's not safe here for you.
I know.
The police still have a lot of questions for Russell Nash.
I can take care of myself. Rachel's emotion builds.
Why are you here, Conner?  After seven years without a word, why have you come back?  You went off to make a new life with Brenda and that was the last I heard-- A sadness falls over Macleod's face.
Brenda's dead. Rachel is stunned.

(continuing) Four years ago.  I've nowhere else to go.  You're all I have, Rachel -- and I'm just so tired of being alone. His words touch her.  She opens a cabinet and pulls out a bottle of GLENMORGANGIE scotch.  Macleod forces a weak sm In the light he looks tired.  She pours him a drink.
It isn't over, is it, Conner?
(wearily) No.
How can that be?
I don't know. Rachel's face fills with compassion.  She reaches out and Macleod.  He lays his head on her shoulder like a baby.

Every inch of wall-space is filled with shelves and BOOKS Macleod walks along a row studying the titles.  A faint g falls across his face as he sees a selected works of poet Rachel enters the room with a tea service and places it o table.
Is there anything else you need?
No -- I'm fine.  Thank you.
I'm glad you've come home, Conner.
Me too. Rachel leaves.  Macleod takes a small book off the shelf looks through it.  Outside a STREAK of LIGHTNING cuts acr the night sky.  Macleod looks out the window concerned.
Seventeenth century Scotland.  The CAMERA rise over an ol stone wall.  A charming farm house with stone walls and a thatched roof sits in the distance.  Smoke drifts lazily the chimney.

A man toils behind an ox, his arms straining as he guides plow through the soft earth.  He stops, runs his hand acr his brow, then turns around.  It is Macleod.  His hair is longer, but he looks exactly the same. The FARMER and owner of the land, a kindly-looking man in fifties walks over to him.  He picks up and handful of so tastes it.
It will be a good harvest this year.
Can you really tell from doing that?
What do you think?
I think you just like to eat dirt. They both LAUGH.  SARAH, fifteen years old, with flaxen h and bright blue eyes approaches Macleod with a water pale
(shyly) Would you care for some water, Conner?
Aye -- that I would, lass. Conner takes the ladle and pours it over his head.  He sc out some more water and drinks, then WINKS at Sarah.  She blushes and runs off.
I think my Sarah fancies you, Conner.
She's a treasure she is.
She'll soon be of age. Macleod understands him only too well.
Your words are kind and they flatter me -- but I think of her as a sister. Besides, you hardly know me.

I know that for six months you've worked hard and asked for little. That you're a good and honest man. What more need I know? The conversation is interrupted by the SOUND of HORSES HO thundering across the fields.  TWO MEN, dirty and rough-l ride up to the house.  They have the look of warriors to The Farmers wife and Sarah stand outside the house.
The Farmer arrives, out of breath from his run across the field.  In the b.g. we see Macleod going into the barn.
Good day. The Men do not answer.  The Farmer is nervous.  He has se like this before.  A few other FARM HANDS, mostly OLD MEN WOMEN come in from the fields.
You are welcome to share our food and our fire.
We do not share, old man.  We take. Warrior #1 dismounts.  His eyes fall on young Sarah.  He back at his friend with a toothless grin.
You can eat if you want.  I'm going to start with her. Warrior #1 walks towards Sarah who clings to her Mother. Farmer stands in the path of the Warrior.

No! Warrior #1 backhands the Farmer across the face, sending falling to the ground.  Sarah tries to run but the Warrio grabs her.  He lifts her over his shoulder and carries he inside the barn, closing the door behind them.  We HEAR S SCREAM.  A beat.  Suddenly, the doors of the barn crash o the Warrior flies out of the barn and lands on his back. Macleod steps out of the barn, his Samurai in hand.  Warr #2, still mounted on his horse grins.
It appears this farmer has a temper. Warrior #1 staggers to his feet.  He removes his sword an stares angrily at Macleod.

This farmer is dead. Warrior #1 lunges at Macleod who casually sidesteps his a and slices his sword across the Warriors chest.  The Warr GASPS, then falls to the ground dead. Warrior #2 cannot believe what he has seen.  Anger fills face.  He reaches to the side of his saddle and lifts a C BOW.  Macleod changes his grip on the sword and holds it spear.  He THROWS it at the Warrior at the same time he F the cross bow.  The sword flies into the Warrior's stomac Blood flows from his mouth.  A beat.  He falls from the s dead. Macleod is standing, an ARROW dead-center in his chest. flows from the wound.  He slowly walks into the barn.  Th Farmer runs after him.

The Farmer enters.  Macleod is on his knees, his face fil with pain.  He pulls the arrow from his chest and stands. farmer cannot believe what he has just seen.  He crosses himself. Outside, through the open barn doors we see Sarah and her mother running towards them.  The Farmer quickly closes t doors and bolts them.
(stunned) This cannot be.
It is.  Do not ask me how.  I do not know.  I must leave, for if I stayed others would surely hear of this and worse than they will come.
Agreed.
(sadly) I would like to say goodbye.
How?
The doors opens and the Farmer comes outside.  He motions his wife and Sarah to enter.
Sarah is crying as she enters with her Mother and Father. Macleod is laying on the ground, his head propped up unde mat of straw.
Be quick -- he has not much time. Tears flow from Sarah's eyes as she kneels next to Macleo She holds his hand.
Don't leave us, Conner.
(weakly) It's not for me to decide. He gently wipes her tears away with his hand.
(continuing) Don't cry, wee one.  It's a better place I go to.
I love you, Conner.
Aye -- I know, Las -- and I have never loved anyone more.
I'll no forget you.
(sadly) And I you.  Go now.  Let me walk to heavens door alone. The Farmer ushers his wife and Sarah from the barn.
The Farmer sits on a cart pulled by an ox.  He stops and around.
This should do. In the back of the cart Macleod lifts up a tarp and gets He looks down in the valley.  He can see the LIGHTS in th FARMHOUSE below.
Go.  I will dig a grave and mark it with your name. The farmer's voice is distant.  He is still unable to gra what he has seen.
Thank you. Macleod reaches up his hand.  The Farmer does not take it Macleod understands.  He starts to walk off into the nigh
Conner? Macleod turns around.

I will not pretend to understand what I have seen this day.  I am a simple man.  Whatever you be -- demon or spirit -- I thank you for the life of my Sarah and I wish you God's peace. The Farmer turns the cart around, leaving Macleod alone, staring into the night.
Macleod is still staring out the window as the memories f back into the past.  He opens the book of poetry and sear through it.
(reading aloud) The forest is lovely.  Dark and deep -- but I have promises to keep -- and miles to go before I sleep. Another FLASH of LIGHTNING.  He looks out the window into night.
(wearily) "Miles to go before I sleep"

The WIND HOWLS through the valley.  Outside the crumbling of the STONE BUILDING (we saw in the opening sequence) ar several four wheel drive trucks and vans.  PROFESSOR PAUL DAJORSKI, is a typical academic in his fifties: beard, gl pipe, tweed jacket.  He walks across the field with a REP and CAMERAMAN.
For years this site was thought to hold no archaeological value.  That is until a few weeks ago when some local boys discovered what appears to be a collapsed passageway that leads into a cavern.
How much longer until you expect to enter the main cavern?
That's what we're going to find out now. A STREAK OF LIGHTNING CUTS across the clear blue sky. Professor Dajorski looks up.
(referring to the lightning) I've never seen anything like that before.
It just started a few hours ago. WORKERS exit the building pushing wheelbarrows filled wit and dirt.  The Professor enters the stone building, follo the Reporter and his team.

Inside groups of VOLUNTEERS attend to various functions. Professor Dajorski walks through the room.  The Camera Cr follows. WE MOVE WITH THEM as they walk down a long tunnel that le into the mountain. JENNIFER HILLMAN an attractive woman in her late twenties stands next to a TECHNICIAN.  They each watch the screen bright green light oscillates up and down.  She looks up Dakorski.
Electro magnetic soundings indicate we've only got a few inches of rock left before we reach the main chamber.
Any idea how big the cavern is on the other side?
Huge.
What are you hoping to find inside? The question strikes Jennifer as odd.
You guys are from the British museum, right?
No -- we're from Strange facts and mysteries.  It's a syndicated show out of..
(to Dajorski) Paul.  I thought we agreed.  No press.
Just a little.  Who knows what we're going to find in there.  It could be a huge excavation.  A little friendly PR never hurt.
Where is the film crew from the British Museum?
They've had a little car trouble. I'm afraid they won't be here until after dark.
Then we shouldn't break into the cavern until tomorrow morning.  This could be a very important find.  I want it documented.
All is quiet.  Trucks and Vans are parked near the struct
A GUARD sits in a fold-out chair at the entrance to the t

ELECTRIC LIGHTS are set up at intervals along the tunnel. HEAR a SCRATCHING SOUND.  A beat.  The SOUND grows LOUDER of the huge rocks blocking the tunnel begins to move.  It forward slowly, then falls to the ground with a THUD.  Th now a hole in the wall.
The GUARD hears the SOUND.  He turns around and looks dow tunnel, then enters.

The Guard reaches the end.  He sees there are now several on the ground and the hole in the wall is now even bigger Guard slowly removes a FLASH LIGHT and moves towards the He shines the light inside and looks in.  A beat -- then, suddenly and hand reaches out, grabbing the Guard and pul him in through the hole.  A beat.  ALL IS QUIET. Kilvara steps out through the hole holding his sword.  He shields his eyes from the light and moves towards the exi
Kilvara steps outside.  He takes a deep breath, filling h lungs with the cool night air.  A moment later he is join the two Horsemen.  Kilvara closes his eyes.
Can you feel it?  There is another one among us.  It has not ended?
What now? Kilvara opens his eyes and slowly looks at the Horseman.

Everything is as it was before. Kilvara raises his sword -- swings in at the Horseman -- severs his head from his body.  The other Horseman looks horror.  He backs up slowly, then runs off.  Kilvara prep himself to receive the power.
A Brilliant GREEN LIGHT pierces the darkness, lighting th front of the Stone Building.
Macleod bolts up in bed.  He stares out the window sadly.

Seventeenth century England. Macleod rides his horse along a road blanketed by dense f on each side.  Suddenly, he stops his horse as a premonit fills him.  He looks around.  A horse is tethered to a tr the road.

Good day. The VOICE comes from above.  Macleod looks up.  Sitting o branch of a tree that extents over the road is THOMAS CAVANAUGH.  He is a large, robust MAN in his fifties dres thick sheepskins.  He drops from the tree landing before Macleod.  Macleod slowly reaches for his Samurai.
You'll have no need for that, Highlander.
Since we hardly know each other, I'm sure you'll understand if I hold one to it for awhile.
Caution shows wisdom. Cavenaugh notes the Samurai.
I know that weapon.  It belonged to Juan Romeriz.  He's dead?
(sadly) Aye.
You?
No.  He was my brother.  He died at anothers hand.
We too are brothers, Macleod.  In fact, you have more family than you think.
Who are you?
Thomas Cavenaugh.  I am a teacher of sorts.  Like Romeriz I help those newly acquainted with our life.
I learned my fill from Romeriz.
Indeed you did.  And now it is time for you to pass on to others what you learned from him. Cavenaugh walks over his horse and mounts it.
So they can take my head? Cavenaugh rides over to Macleod.

Your head is not important, Highlander.  What is important is the prize.  It must go to one who would not misuse it.  Ride with me.  Come and meet your family. Cavenaugh's horse begins to walk away.  Macleod stares af him, then follows.
The Church stands alone in a valley, it's stone walls col from time and neglect.  Fog carpets the ground.  HORSES a CARTS are in front of the building.

Only three of the four stone walls are standing.  A large section of the roof is gone.  Inside are about thirty MEN WARRIORS, fierce and hard-looking.  They stand before wha was the altar and listen as Cavenaugh speaks.

I've called this gathering on holy ground so that each man might take comfort in knowing he is protected inside the confines of these walls. None of us, good or evil would dare raise a hand against the other in God's house.
If God protects us so, why has he cursed us?
God's purpose for us is unclear, save that he has given us a gift.
A gift?  You call never growing old - - watching friends and loved ones die a gift?

I do not profess to know what is in God's mind.  He has chosen us.  We are his warriors through time.  The final Gathering is still far away but the prize must be captured by a man who is pure of heart.  Those of us who would use the prize for goodly purpose must band together against those who would use it for evil. In the back of the room, standing alone is Macleod.  His are on the altar, but his mind seems far away.
Macleod walks with Cavanaugh, weaving through the crowd o and horses.
The prize?  So much blood so that in the end the one that remains will be mortal again.  So much pain so that the winner can grow old and have children.  The prize hardly seems worth the cost of it.
There will be more to the prize than that.  Power will come with it -- and it must be used for good.
The days of magic are ending.  The world is changing.

Aye -- yet one such as I who has wandered this world for nearly nine centuries can remember back to other days of change.  Days of Robin of the Hood and Arthur Pendragon.  They were real enough once, but they drifted into men's dreams and became legend - - as we shall do one day. Macleod stops at his horse.
I grow weary of the fight. Macleod mounts his horse.
You cannot run from your destiny, Conner.
Perhaps -- but if I must face it, let it find me, for I shall search for it no more.
Professor Dajorski walks quickly to the Stone Building. area is surprisingly empty.  Jennifer walks over to meet
What's going on?  Where is everyone?
We're holding the workers down below.
Why?
Someone broke into the cavern last night.
What?  How? Jennifer begins to walk.  Dajorski follows.
We're not quite sure.  The Guard was knocked out. Dajorski is concerned.  Jennifer waves him off.
He's fine.  He swears he never left his post for a moment.  He heard a noise and when he went back to look they were already inside.
How could they get by him?
I don't know. Jennifer stops.  A few feet away lies the torso of the ho covered by a blanket.  Beside him, covered with a jacket head.  Dajorski looks at it.
(pointing) We found him this morning.
(pointing) What's that next to him?
His head.  Someone cut it off. Dajorski shivers at the thought of it.
Look at this. Jennifer lifts the cloth.  Dajorski isn't pleased with th sight, but he immediately sees what she is referring to. bends down and examines the dead man's clothing.
Incredible.  The cloth -- the buttons -- it looks to be mid sixteen hundreds.  It's a remarkable duplication.
I don't think it is a duplication.
It has to be.
And this? Jennifer lifts the sword.  Dajorski examines it.
Same period -- and exceptionally well preserved.  Jennifer, what's going on here? Jennifer look back at the stone building.
That's a good question.  That's a very good question.
Macleod comes out of the elevator.  He walks over to Rach the counter.
